awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Designing Individualized Privacy and Security Systems
awd_abstract_narration: This project explores the extent to which personality traits predict privacy and security behaviors. Over the past decade, computer privacy and security have improved by leaps and bounds by considering human factors in the design process. However, previous work to improve the usability of privacy and security systems has only examined the behaviors of "average users," which is believed to only yield local maxima because no individual perfectly fits this profile. Therefore, this project is examining the extent to which additional improvements can be made by catering system designs to individual differences (e.g., in personality traits). Through a series of surveys and controlled experiments, researchers are discovering how these personality traits are predictive of certain privacy decisions, as well as interactions with various security mitigations. For instance, knowledge of a user's personality traits may result in more appropriate default privacy settings on a social networking website or web browser security warnings that are more salient to that user. The researchers' goal is to ultimately design systems that infer personality traits and then adjust privacy and security mechanisms so as to yield outcomes that are optimally aligned with a particular user's preferences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
We examined whether security and privacy systems can be improved by catering to individual personality traits. In the past decade, system designers and software engineers have realized that they need to account for human factors, and this has resulted in more usable systems. However, these systems still come up short in that they are now designed for the "average user," but no individual perfectly fits this description. Our grand vision for the future is a world in which systems can automatically adapt their interfaces and messaging on an individual basis, thus maximizing their effectiveness by appealing to individual users' traits.

Systems could make inferences about personality traits and preferences based on observed behavior and then use these observations to customize interactions, such as only warning about risks that are concerning to the user or automatically adjusting privacy decisions based on inferred privacy preferences. As a first step in conducting this research agenda, we performed a series of experiments to demonstrate that well-studied measures in the psychology literature could be used to predict privacy and security attitudes and behaviors.

One of our most interesting findings was that the "Big 5" personality traits (Extraversion, Openness to New Experiences, Consciousness, Agreeableness, and Emotional Stability), which are one of the most commonly used measures in the literature, are a very poor predictor of privacy attitudes. Instead, we observed that measures relating to decision-making style and risk atittudes are much stronger predictors of both privacy and security attitudes. Therefore, future research should focus on using these types of measures when attempting to predict users' privacy and security attitudes.

Additionally, this grant resulted in the development of the Security Behavior Intentions Scale (SeBIS), which is used to quantify users' security attitudes. In the privacy literature, various scales exist for measuring the gap between privacy attitudes and observed privacy protective behaviors (the so-called "privacy paradox"). Yet, prior to our development of the SeBIS, no standard metric existed for measuring security attitudes. Without quantifying security intentions/attitudes, one cannot adequately determine why a particular security mitigation is failing users. The SeBIS will help us to identify when poor security practices are the result of poor intentions, as opposed to poor usability, for instance. The scale is also a benefit to security researchers because it can be used as a proxy for security behaviors when performing future research studies.

This foundational work has shown us how privacy and security attitudes differ from individual to individual and how these differences can be predicted.
